bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, March 6, 1941

div1.p: Kean discusses the layout of Camp Lazear. He thinks the location of Camp Lazear is settled by Rojas' daybook entries. He wrote to Dominguez and pointed out the errors in his book.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, March 6, 1941
div1.p:
Here are your memorandum for
Dr. Ramas and all the pieces justificatives
including the very interesting photographs. In the
envelope with the latter is my letter to His Exe.
Señor Dr Ramos - If I should rewrite it I could
improve it, as to the English, but I cannot bear
to undertake it and think that it will do as
it is- I have had to do a lot of writing lately
about one thing or another and get very tired of
the pen especially as I do not write rapidly-
You will certainly be loaded for bear when you
arrive in Havana this time Dr. Lage et als will
not have a leg to stand on- Your photostat of
Sr. Ignacio Rajos's entries in his day-book settle
the matter especially with my testimony in my letter-
I have written two letters to Dr. Francisco Dominguez
about his book and have pointed out some errors in
it, which he wont like, Also I could not help
quoting the dictum of Dr. Gold berger of the Public Health
Service who did notable work in the study of Mexican
typhus and pellagra- His dictum was “The work of
Reed(?)
converted a discredited theory into an established
doctrine”- I was always careful however to speak
of Finlay as the discoverer-

I wrote you yesterday about the finding at the
Army Medical Museum of the Contract of Reed
with Antonio Benigno - You should get
my letter today-

Will I must stop and do a little
work on my Income Tax Return which is some-
what complicated by the fact the Mrs Kean owns
a couple of little houses which raised all sorts
of troublesome questions of repairs deterivatives etc
